article.title: Novel organelles with elements of bacterial and eukaryotic secretion systems weaponize parasites of Drosophila

sections.introduction: The evolutionary success of parasitoid wasps, a highly diverse group of insects widely used in biocontrol, depends on a variety of life history strategies in conflict with those of their hosts [1]. Drosophila melanogaster is a natural host of parasitic wasps of the genus Leptopilina.
sections.results: Larvae of parasitic wasps of the Leptopilina genus feed on Drosophila larval host tissues, and eclose into free-living adults (Fig 1 A).
sections.discussion: The composition of Lh VLPs is complex and interesting in multiple respects but the most conspicuous observations are an absence of viral structural proteins and the presence of conserved eukaryotic proteins with microvesicular signature.

article.insights_summary: The composition of Lh VLPs is complex and interesting in multiple respects but the most conspicuous observations are an absence of viral structural proteins and the presence of conserved eukaryotic proteins with microvesicular signature.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to thank E. Miller, J. Crissman, & J. Berriman, along with Govind and Singh lab members (M. Badri, H. Chiu, A. Hudgins, J. Morales, I. Paddibhatala, R. Rajwani, S. Shamburger, and B. Wey) for discussions, experimental assistance, and reagents.
